utterances: Hey, Farai.
So Tony, tell me about this sports blogosphere.
Well, you know, Farai, this is something new for us here at NEWS & NOTES, a sports Bloggers' Roundtable.
The sports blog has increasingly become a way for fans to read about the things that they're thinking and talking about.
Justin Grant is a writer for Alphablogsports.
Mike Tillery, he writes for the blog The Starting Five, and Gregory Lee is online sports editor for The Boston Globe.
Gentlemen, welcome to NEWS & NOTES.
Hello.
Hi.
How you doing?
Hello.
How you doing?
Let's start with this one.
What exactly - Justine, I'm going to bring this to you.
What exactly is the sport blog offering that other forms of media are not?
Well, basically, the sports blog is taking readers behind the stories of what you're going to find in a newspaper.
You got to find different irreverent type of things, things that you would not find in mainstream news.
And then also, you have different blogs such as Deadspin.com, where you actually get some nice takes on, you know, just - let's go on in the world of sports.
And you'll also find some - you get to see players in compromising positions.
You might find athletes - there was actually a link on Deadspin to the Boston Red Sox celebrating the AL East crown at a bar, getting drunk.
So that's the type of thing that you're going to find on the sports blogging.
(Unintelligible).
Well, Mike, who are these bloggers?
Are they casual or die-hard fans?
I think the bloggers are very die-hard fans.
Some of them are casual.
Some of them just want to get across their opinions of sports in a casual fashion.
And then, you have other writers that want to be more serious, or it just really depends on what type of genre that they want to write in.
Well, Greg, you are all African-American bloggers and you're reading other blogs out there, of course.
What makes black blogs unique in a blogosphere, or are they?
I think, first, there really aren't many black bloggers out as with just journalism or just in this sphere.
We're just starting to get into it.
But the difference is from what I've read from the various black bloggers I've seen out there, we bring in, you know, a different perspective of how we see things.

We bring in more of an edge that's a little bit more colorful, brings a little bit more, you know, hip-hoppish-type of thing, a little pop culture but more of - sometimes I see it as more of a street thing, which is cool.

It's a different take than, you know, the type of humor that I'm accustomed to than, you know, some other bloggers made, some other bigger bloggers who - some of their humor I can't really get into, can't get into because I can't really relate.
So blacks and black bloggers bring voice to things that I've seen, you know, through my experience.
Stay with us.
DAY TO DAY continues in a moment.
Well, she hasn't been interested in walking away.
But there have been big calls for Pelosi to step aside, especially from younger activists who feel like the party looks more like yesterday rather than tomorrow.
And they've been trying to push her to think about...
Is that a dig at diversity?

(Laughter) No. And so the point is that they feel like that there are people who are - the three top leaders in the House are all over 70 years old and that they would like to see millennials and younger people, who've been waiting for a while and have - and feel like that these older generation of Democrats have been standing in the way.
She is a politician with three - with 30 years of experience under her belt, right?
I mean, that can't be all bad for the party.
No, definitely not.
Pelosi's got a lot of strengths.
I mean, she's one of the strongest fundraisers in the party, if not the strongest.
She's raised $16 million just in the first quarter alone here.
And that can't be discounted in a year when Democrats are looking to win back the House.
You know, she's been at the helm of the Democratic party since when Democrats took over the House in 2007.
She shepherded key legislation for President Barack Obama through really a fractious cautious - caucus with no drama whatsoever, which is not something Republican leaders can say for sure.

You know, a Democratic operative I spoke with today said that no one is better at getting and counting votes than she is and contended that no one would be better at getting things done with Trump as president.
You could argue that.
But they think that she's pretty tough, can get things done.
Another Democrat, though, described her as easily the most effective speaker in a generation but added, I do think it's time to usher in a new era.
And even the earlier Democrat that I talked to said that he thinks that she should step aside in 2020 when President Trump is running for re-election.
She is also easily a political villain - right?
- to Republicans.
Yeah.

And this is the big reason why they would like to see the air sort of taken out of that because, you know, San Francisco liberal is something you hear in Republican ads, ad after ad, in swing districts.
And it's not used as a compliment.
You know, one analysis found that one out of every three ads this cycle, Republican ads this cycle, are using Pelosi's image to attack the Democrat that's running.
There's reasons that they do this.
Republicans found that Pelosi's the most unpopular figure in those swing districts.

An NBC national poll earlier in March found that she's the least popular person or institution, that of everyone that they rated, her approval rating's in the 20s, lower than both political parties and even President Trump.
That's why Democrats in swing districts, the places that Democrats need to win to take back the House, are distancing themselves from Pelosi.
One Republican operative I talked to today said he's ecstatic that Pelosi is going to try to run for speaker again if they win.
Is that enough to win midterms?
I mean, that's the big question, right?
Just running against Pelosi is going to open up Republicans to criticism that they don't have a message.
Domenico, thanks so much.
You're welcome.

So, the very name rapture terrifies people.
Was this a terrifying raptor?
I think, indeed, that name is well put.
These animals were incredibly fast, incredibly intelligent and some of them wielded very significant claws and sharp teeth.
So it's a good notion.
How big was this raptor?
This is not a terribly huge animal.
I mean contrary to something like the velociraptors that we saw in ""Jurassic Park,"" this animal was only maybe five feet long about two-and-a-half feet at the hips.
Well, big enough to do some damage though, right?
Definitely - definitely an overgrown, vicious Labrador retriever-sized animal.
And I've read it had feathers?
Yes, we know that this group of dinosaurs would have been feathered.

In fact, this particular group of dinosaurs was very, very closely related to modern birds, which are in fact living dinosaurs that made it through that mass extinction event 65 million years ago, and are still living along side of us today.
So does this raptor have a short, nasty, brutish life or is it hard to say?
So I think that finding Talos was something that we were all waiting for.
And it was a confirmation of something that we'd been speculating about for a long time.
Does he have a name, like Suzy...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
...there was one there in Chicago?
Well, no. But in a very real way, given that I named the species name after a good friend and colleague of mine, Scott Sampson, who is the...
